image.altText: DeanYates

items.synopsis: WikiLeaks leaked a video showing two of former foreign correspondent Dean Yates's colleagues being killed. The truth left him reeling.

title.children: 'I felt responsible': Dean was guilt-ridden his staff died on his watch. Then WikiLeaks released the footage

image.altText: A man with a moustache and nose ring wearing a hat leans against a tree trunk.

items.synopsis: As Australians prepare to vote in a historic referendum, the ABC's Voice correspondent Dan Bourchier travels to the north, west and east of the country for Four Corners and finds a nation grappling with its future.

title.children: Ben was going to vote Yes to the Voice. Now he's a hard No

image.altText: A brown snake with its tongue out on a rock

items.synopsis: Experts say how you respond in the minutes after a snake bite could be the difference between life and death. It comes after the tragic death of a man bitten by a suspected brown snake while trying to save a friend in North Queensland.

title.children: Snake season has turned deadly. Here's what to do if you get bitten

image.altText: danny in hospital with his parents

items.synopsis: Danny has leukaemia and needs a bone marrow transplant. The life-saving treatment will cost his family half a million dollars.

title.children: Six-year-old Danny needs a bone marrow transplant, but he's not covered by Medicare

items.synopsis: Data released from Copernicus, a branch of the European Union Space Programme, shows August was 1.59C warmer than 1850–1900 levels, following a 1.6C increase in July.

title.children: Global temperatures exceed 1.5C above pre-industrial levels for first time

image.altText: Novak Djokovic holds a silver trophy

items.synopsis: Novak Djokovic extends his dominance in men's tennis with a straight-sets victory over Daniil Medvedev to claim his 24th grand slam singles title and his fourth at the US Open.

title.children: 'What are you still doing here?': Dominant Djokovic wins record-equalling US Open title

image.altText: A dingo looks out from atop a hill

items.synopsis: Rangers are pleading with visitors to K'gari to heed warnings about dingoes ahead of school holidays as another one is destroyed due to its dangerous interactions with humans.

title.children: Rangers euthanase dingo involved in high-risk attacks, the third to be destroyed this year

image.altText: Tens set up in a park beneath a bridge.

items.synopsis: Three hot meals a day, food hampers, a shower and a place to rest — simple services are making life easier for those on the streets of Bundaberg.

title.children: A place that looks after its most vulnerable, Bundaberg becomes a beacon for the homeless

image.altText: AFL players playing a game

items.synopsis: Two men have been charged with assaulting police officers after spectators stormed the field at a country AFL final in Queensland.

title.children: Police officers allegedly assaulted after 'disgusting' incident at outback AFL grand final

image.altText: A young boy looking at the camera while kneeling near a pile of rubble.

items.synopsis: Everyone left in Moulay Ibrahim has a story of their narrow escape — just ask 11-year-old Abdarazak Abou Aalam, whose tragic tour of the town starts at his neighbour's house, which was destroyed in Friday's earthquake.

title.children: In this devastated Moroccan village, an 11yo earthquake survivor gives a tour of the rubble

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: Spanish Football Federation chief Luis Rubiales, engulfed in a scandal over giving an unsolicited kiss to a player on the women's World Cup team last month, says he will resign from his position.

title.children: Spain's soccer chief Luis Rubiales announces resignation over unsolicited kiss

image.altText: A school zone sign in front of a tree

items.synopsis: In the first three weeks of operation the cameras, distributed from Cairns all the way to the Gold Coast, issued 1,607 fines to speeding drivers – the equivalent of 100 penalties every school day.

title.children: After 'technical issues' Queensland's school zone cameras are snapping 500 drivers each week

image.altText: Silhouette of Sydney CBD covered in smoke haze on September 11, 2023

items.synopsis: Smoke settles across many areas of Sydney as hazard reduction burning by the NSW Rural Fire Service continues ahead of a forecast warm and dry weekend.

title.children: Air quality 'very poor' in Sydney's east as firefighters 'catch up' on hazard reduction burning

image.altText: A dark-haired man in his 30s and his mother, about 60, sit in front of a tent with their two dogs.

items.synopsis: Matt Turner has a job and perfect tenancy references, but the housing crisis has left him at his lowest point.

title.children: There are 40 vacant houses nearby, so why is this employed 34yo living in a tent with his mum?

image.altText: planes on an airport runway

items.synopsis: Qantas' board remains under pressure ahead of its annual report, including over whether former CEO Alan Joyce should receive his full bonus, and what the board knew about the ACCC's ghost flights investigation. Meanwhile, the ASX has opened lower. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas board under pressure over Joyce bonus and ghost flights, tech stocks await iPhone 15 release, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A dip in the price of iron ore is all in response to comments made by the Chinese government in recent days. On Friday, they warned some market players not to hype up prices for the steelmaking ingredient in response to another price rally, and its state planner also pledged to step up its regulatory oversight of the market. China is the world's biggest producer of steel, and buys about two-thirds of global seaborne iron ore. "Iron ore edged lower as Beijing targets market exuberance," ANZ commodity strategists said in a note. "Regulators told futures companies in a recent meeting to not deliberately exaggerate the atmosphere of iron ore price rallies and to analyse the market objectively." China's iron ore imports in August climbed 13.8% from July, fuelled by growing demand from steel mills ramping up production ahead of peak construction months. Their excitement was also bolstered by Beijing's policy support for the domestic economy amid a stalling recovery. However, the outlook for iron ore demand beyond China's traditional September-October peak season is clouded by likely steel production cuts intended to curb carbon emissions. — with Reuters.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What caused the price of iron ore to fall recently?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The board of the Bendigo and Adelaide Bank has announced David Foster will be the bank's next chairman, after Jacqueline Hey decided to retire after more than 12 years. Ms Hey joined the board in July 2011 and was appointed as its chair in 2019. She was the first woman to hold the position in the bank's history. She will retire after the bank's annual general meeting on October 24. Mr Foster has been on the bank's board since 2019. He chairs its financial risk committee and is a member of its people, culture and transformation committee. He was previously the CEO of Suncorp Bank from 2008 to 2013. "It has been a privilege to serve with Jacquie on the board and I am pleased to be appointed chair of Bendigo and Adelaide Bank," he said. "I look forward to building on the strong progress that has been made under Jacquie's thoughtful stewardship and continue delivering on the bank's purpose. "As chair my focus will be to prioritise sustainable growth and ensure that the bank continues to improve its performance for the benefit of our customers, people, partners, communities and shareholders as we execute on our vision to be Australia's bank of choice."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bendigo and Adelaide Bank appoints David Foster as next chair

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket has opened lower on Monday, down 0.2% to 7,414 points as of 10:25am AEST. (For live figures at any time, jump to the post at the top of the blog.) A disappointing financial forecast from scrap recycler Sims has dragged the market lower, after it forecast it would break even during the first quarter of the 2024 financial year because of ongoing demand issues and the scrap price. Tech stocks have also pulled the market lower, with Block down around 4% in the early session, in response to Friday's outage. As for the sectors, industrials is down 1.5%, real estate down 0.8%, and healthcare and technology down 0.5% each. Energy and academic and educational services are up 0.4% each, and financials has gained 0.3%. The top five movers so far: Syrah Resources +11.4% PEXA Group +3% Imugene +2.5% Magellan Financial Group +2.4% Evolution Mining +1.8% The bottom five performers so far: Sims -11.8% Lake Resources -5.3% Megaport -4.8% Chorus -4.3% Block -4.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX dragged lower by tech stocks, Sims disappointing financial forecast

image.altText: Listen Out Festival in Sydney, 2018

items.synopsis: Your place for today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Calls for pill testing in NSW ahead of summer music festival season. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tasmania Police have found the boat belonging to a man who failed to return from a fishing trip in the state's north yesterday. Kerry Frankombe's 6 metre half cab dinghy was located at 1.30am off Beechford which is roughly 40 kilometres east and 12 kilometres off-shore from where he set out off Port Sorell. Significant searches are continuing for the 75-year-old. Police say there was no EPIRB activation, and Mr Frankombe did not have a mobile phone with him. Police would like to speak to anyone who may have seen the boat and the Deloraine man.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Boat found for missing Tasmanian fisher

featuredLink.title: Empty boat found at sea after Tasmanian man embarks on fishing trip

children.content: Tasmania Police have found the boat belonging to a man who failed to return from a fishing trip in the state's north yesterday.
Kerry Frankombe's 6 metre half cab dinghy was located at 1.30am off Beechford which is roughly 40 kilometres east and 12 kilometres off-shore from where he set out off Port Sorell.
Significant searches are continuing for the 75-year-old.
Police say there was no EPIRB activation, and Mr Frankombe did not have a mobile phone with him.
Police would like to speak to anyone who may have seen the boat and the Deloraine man.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Another dingo on Queensland island, K'gari (Fraser Island), has been euthanised by wildlife rangers, making it the third destroyed this year. The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service says the dingo was humanely euthanased at the weekend after being closely monitored since January. The service said it had recorded six "high-risk" interactions involving the animal with children, adults and rangers. More details here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dingo euthanised on K'gari (Fraser Island)

featuredLink.title: Rangers euthanase dingo involved in high-risk attacks, the third animal to be destroyed this year

children.content: Another dingo on Queensland island, K'gari (Fraser Island), has been euthanised by wildlife rangers, making it the third destroyed this year.
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service says the dingo was humanely euthanased at the weekend after being closely monitored since January.
The service said it had recorded six "high-risk" interactions involving the animal with children, adults and rangers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Advocates are urging the New South Wales government to set up a pill testing trial before the summer festival season to help reduce drug-related harm. In an open letter to Premier Chris Minns, more than a dozen experts and advocates say heat is known to increase the risk of taking unknown substances. Unharm CEO Dr Will Tregoning told ABC Radio New South Wales must follow the lead of other jurisdictions which have implemented similar measures. "It's a service that's been delivered for over a year now by the CANtest consortium in the ACT," he said. "So these are effective, simple, proven ways that we can make people safer this summer."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Calls for pill-testing ahead of summer festival season

featuredLink.title: Calls for urgent pill testing trial before summer festival season

children.content: Advocates are urging the New South Wales government to set up a pill testing trial before the summer festival season to help reduce drug-related harm.
In an open letter to Premier Chris Minns, more than a dozen experts and advocates say heat is known to increase the risk of taking unknown substances.
Unharm CEO Dr Will Tregoning told ABC Radio New South Wales must follow the lead of other jurisdictions which have implemented similar measures.
"It's a service that's been delivered for over a year now by the CANtest consortium in the ACT," he said.
"So these are effective, simple, proven ways that we can make people safer this summer."

items.synopsis: China made it much harder for money to leave the country in 2017. Our study looked at Sydney home prices before and after that crackdown — and these are the suburbs where we found they changed, writes Song Shi.

title.children: How much did Chinese investors drive up Sydney home prices?

image.altText: A little boy in a fluffy hoodie plays with his mother in a living room.

image.altText: Composite image of Darcy Moore, Nic Newman and Charlie Cameron.

title.children: Four-day week enshrined in first Australian union agreement, with concept spreading

items.synopsis: Premier Daniel Andrews's new inquiry has been tasked with untangling a web of horrors relating to just 18 Victorian government schools. The single case of serial paedophile headmaster William Landman shows why a broader examination is needed, writes investigative reporter Russell Jackson.

title.children: Prolific paedophile William Landman was a criminal before he was a teacher. He and other abusers will not be examined in a new inquiry

image.altText: A woman working on a laptop in a board room.

title.children: Nice work if you can get it: Australian boardrooms dominated by men earning over $1m despite more female directors
